bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to L. O. Howard, January 15, 1901

div1.p: Reed thanks Howard for sending him Woldert's suggestion about how best to use kerosene in eradicating mosquitoes, and asks for more information concerning the genus of the yellow fever mosquito. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to L. O. Howard, January 15, 1901
div1.opener:
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
* 1934 *
LITTERA
SCRIPTA
MANET
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, Bureau of
Entomology and Plant Quarantine.
Three Centimeters
DIVISION OF ENTOMOLOGY
* JAN 22 1901 *
Answered by Letter
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
January 15, 1901.
My dear Mr Howard:
div1.p:
I have
yours of the 10th containing
MDr Wolfert's suggestion
as to the best & most
Economical manner
of using Kerosene on
mosquito breeding pools,
& will notify the Chief
Surgeon and the Chief
Sanitary Officer, Dr. Gor-
gas, of Havana - I know
that they will gladly give
it a trial. I was ex-
tremely interested in your
postscript in which you
speak of the almost certain
identity of C. Taeniatus and C.
Fasciatus and that Theobald
separates Taeniatus from Culex
& makes a new genus of it.
This to me is intensely ab-
sorbing just at this stage
of our work. Perhaps,
after all, Culex will not
propagate yellow fever
and that stegomyia is alone
the intermediate host.
This would be impor-
tant indeed, if it proves
to be true. Please tell me
on what grounds Theobald
separates Taeniatus from
Culex - I am very anxious
to know, if you will kindly
tell me. Just now I am busy preparing
our paper for the Pan - American Congress
and hope to have it finished early next
week. We think that our results are
well worth reporting and that they will
entirely revolutionize the views heretofore
held as to the propagation of yellow fever.
Please let me hear about Theobald's reasong
for making Taeniatus a new genius.

closer.seg:
P.S. I thank you very
much for your Reprint of
The Insect Fauna of
Human Excrement - It came
in the last mail.
